Huzhou Institute of Zhejiang University Huzhou Zhejiang 313000 China Herein, three qualities of ammonium phosphate were used to investigate the influence of phosphorylation on the NH3-SCR activity of the CeO2-TA catalyst synthesized via the thiourea hydrothermal method. The results demonstrated that when the molar ratio of P/Ce was 0.1, the introduced ammonium phosphate was beneficial to the formation of highly disperse amorphous sulfates and active CePO4 on CeO2-TA surface, thus enhanced the surface total oxygen/adsorbed oxygen concentrations, the redox properties and the intermediate-strong acid sites of catalyst, which might be responsible for the better NH3-SCR activity of P0.1-CeO2-TA than CeO2-TA. However, the introduction of excessive ammonium phosphate promoted the formation of monoclinic CePO4 and reduced the formed quantity of amorphous sulfates on CeO2-TA surface, which were harmful to the redox properties and acid sites of catalyst. Therefore, the introduced ammonium phosphate decreased the NH3-SCR activity of CeO2-TA when the P/Ce molar ratio increased from 0.1 to 1.0. Graphical Abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Selective catalytic reduction (SCR) Cerium oxide amorphous sulfates phosphorylation CePO4 Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Nitrogen oxides (NO x ) emissions from the combustion of fossil fuels have been proven to cause a series of environmental problems, including photochemical smog, severe haze, acid rain and so on [1,2]. Thus, it is an urgent priority to reduce NO x . Owing to the high de-NO x efficiency and N2 selectivity, selective catalytic reduction with ammonia (NH3-SCR) has been confirmed to be the predominant NO x abatement technology [3–9]. However, there still exists some problems for the commercial V2O5-WO3(MoO3)/TiO2 catalysts in applications, for example, the narrow operation temperature range, the poor high-temperature N2 selectivity and the secondary pollution due to the toxicity of volatile V2O5 [10–13]. Therefore, it is necessary to develop the environment-friendly vanadium-free catalysts, for instance, Iron [14], Cupper [15], Tungsten [16], Manganese [17,18] and Cerium [19] and other metal oxides [20] have been fabricated to replace the commercial V2O5-WO3(MoO3)/TiO2 catalysts in recent decades. Due to the outstanding oxygen storage capacity and good potential redox ability via the electronic cycle of Ce4+/Ce3+ pairs, Ce-based catalysts have been widely developed and present good catalytic performance in many prospects [21–24]. Meanwhile, pure CeO2 exhibits poor NH3-SCR activity owing to some unsatisfactory shortcomings, including the small specific surface area, limited redox ability and little acid sites [25]. It is largely recognized that the acid sites and redox properties are critical to the de-NO x performance of catalyst, and the excellent surface acidity helps to facilitate the adsorption of NH3 and NO x reactants, thus boosts the NH3-SCR process of catalyst [26]. Besides, the appropriate redox properties contribute to activating the adsorbed reactants on catalyst surfaces, and the weak redox capacity could suppress this activation process while the over-strong redox ability might result in the non-selective catalytic oxidation of NH3, especially at high temperature [27]. Thus, many efforts have been made to regulate the redox ability and acidity of cerium oxide, for example, the introduction of protonic acid species, including SO4 2−, PO4 3−, NO3 − and heteropoly acid, has been proven to enhance its surface acidity [28–31]. Among the investigated acids, phosphate presents the excellent thermal stability, abundant acid sites, ion exchange ability and proton conductivity, and the phosphorus modified cerium-based composite oxide achieves high NO x reduction [32,33]. You et al. [34] pointed out that the doping of phosphorus enhanced the surface oxygen mobility of CeO2 and contributed to the regeneration of active sites due to the improved surface Ce3+ and adsorbed oxygen concentrations, and the surface formed amorphous CePO4 increased the redox ability of catalyst, thus improved the NH3-SCR activity of CeO2. It was also reported that the formed PO4 − could be used as the acceptor of proton to enhance the Brønsted acid sites of CeO2 and resulted in the formation of more surface oxygen vacancies, thereby facilitated the de-NO x performance of CeO2 [29]. Moreover, the crystal phase and morphology of Ce-O-P/CePO4 had been found to affect the acidity and active oxygen on the phosphorus modified CeO2 catalyst surface, thus influenced its NH3-SCR activity [35,36]. Zeng et al. [37] pointed out that the redox sites and the NH3 adsorption sites of CeO2-CePO4 nanorods composites were dominated by CeO2 and the P sites of CePO4, respectively. Therefore, phosphate is an effective accelerator to optimize the NH3-SCR activity of cerium-based catalyst. Similar to the promotional effect of phosphate, the introduction of sulfate species also optimizes the acid sites of cerium oxide and facilitates its catalytic performance of NO x reduction by improving the adsorption of NH3 on catalyst surfaces [38]. Liu et al. [39] found that the S-doped CeO2 catalyst presented superior NH3-SCR activity and excellent SO2 tolerance at low/medium-temperatures, and the induced Ce4+-SO4 2− pair sites played as the key factor on inhibiting the oxidation of SO2 and the deposition of NH4HSO4 on catalyst surfaces, which was also proven by DFT calculations. In our previous study, the using of thiourea as the sulfur sources and structure-directing agent contributed in regulating the morphology of cubic fluorite CeO2 and improving the surface acidity and oxygen vacancies of catalyst, resulting in enhancement of the NH3-SCR activity [40]. Meanwhile, the deposition of surface ammonium bisulfate or/and the excessive bulk sulfation are harmful to the de-NO x activity of CeO2 [41]. Xie et al. [42] investigated the effect of sulfate deposition on the physicochemical properties of cerium-based catalyst and found that the excessive adsorbed sulfate inhibited the surface adsorption and activation of oxygen and decreased the redox ability of catalyst. Moreover, the sulfation treatment was also found to weaken the redox capacity of CeO2 although it induced and strengthened the Brønsted sites of catalyst [43]. Therefore, the introduction of certain amount sulfate or phosphate helps to optimize the NH3-SCR activity of CeO2 by improving the surface acid sites, but they present different effects on the redox capacity of catalyst. Meanwhile, the relative influence of sulfate and phosphate modification is unclear, and the effect of phosphate on the physicochemical properties and de-NO x performance of the sulfated CeO2 has also been rarely investigated. In this work, a certain of ammonium phosphate has been used to investigate the effect of phosphate introduction on the NH3-SCR activity of the thiourea modified CeO2-TA catalyst synthesized via a one-pot hydrothermal method. The introduced amount of ammonium phosphate plays an important role on the de-NO x catalytic performance of CeO2-TA. Among the investigated catalysts, P0.1-CeO2-TA displays the best NH3-SCR activity when the P/Ce molar ratio is 0.1. Furthermore, the crystal structure, pore structure, redox abilities and surface acidity were characterized to reveal the influence of ammonium phosphate introduction via a series of characterization techniques, including scanning electron microscopy (SEM), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM), energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS), X-ray diffraction (XRD), N2 adsorption-desorption, Raman, Electron paramagnetic resonance spectra (EPR), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), H2 temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) and NH3 temperature-programmed desorption (NH3-TPD). 2 Experimental Section 2.1 Catalysts preparation and activity tests According to our previous research [40], CeO2-TA was synthesized via a one-pot hydrothermal synthesis method by using cerium nitrate (Ce(NO3)3⋅6H2O), ammonium bicarbonate (NH4HCO3), hydrogen peroxide (H2O2, 30 wt.%) and thiourea (CS(NH2)2) as the cerium source, the precipitant, the oxidant and the sulfur source, respectively. On this basis, a series of P x -CeO2-TA (x = 0.1, 0.5, 1.0) catalysts were synthesized by introducing ammonium phosphate ((NH4)3PO4) into the oxidized solution of hydrogen peroxide before the hydrothermal treatment, where x represents the molar ratio of P and Ce elements. Before the NH3-SCR activity test, all P x -CeO2-TA (x = 0, 0.1, 0.5, 1.0) catalysts had been calcined at 400°C in air for 5 h. The de-NO x performance evaluation was carried out in a fixed bed micro-reactor using 0.45 g catalyst (40-60 mesh) corresponding to the gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) of 200,000 mL/(g⋅h). The typical reactant gases were composed of 600 ppm NH3, 600 ppm NO, and 5 vol.% O2 balanced with 99.999 vol.% N2. A T-350 flue gas analyzer (Testo Company, Germany) was used to obtain the concentrations of O2 and NO x in the simulated flue gas. The NO x conversion could be calculated according to the following equations: (1) N O x conversion ( % ) = [ N O x ] in − [ N O x ] out [ N O x ] in × 100 % Herein, [NO x ]out and [NO x ]in represent the outlet and inlet concentration of NO x (NO x = NO + NO2) at stable state, respectively. 2.2 Catalyst characterizations A series of characterization techniques including SEM, TEM/HR-TEM, XRD, N2 adsorption-desorption, Raman, EPR, XPS, H2-TPR and NH3-TPD were used to investigate the influence of ammonium phosphate introduction on the physicochemical properties of CeO2-TA. SEM images were recorded on the ZEISS SIGMA HD instrument. TEM and HR-TEM-EDS were conducted on the Thermo Fischer Talos F200x instrument operated at 200 kV. Each sample was dispersed in absolute ethanol with ultrasonic oscillation before the analysis and the mixture solution was deposited on a copper grid for testing. X-ray diffraction measurements were performed on the 6100 X-ray diffraction Analyzer (Rigaku, Japan) with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 0.15406 nm) between 10 o and 80 o with a scan rate of 2 o/min. The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm was recorded on a Micromeritics ASAP 2460 system instrument at -196°C. Before the measurements, the catalysts were degassed in a vacuum at 300°C for 5 h. The specific surface area was obtained according to the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) equation while the average pore diameters and total pore volumes of samples were calculated via the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method. Raman spectra was collected on a Raman microscope (InVia Reflex, Reinshaw) with a 532 nm semiconductor laser at room temperature. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were carried out on the ESCALAB 250Xi photoelectron spectrometer (Thermo Fisher Scientific, USA) equipped with Al Kα radiation (1486.7 eV), and the C 1s binding energy value located at 284.8 eV was used as a standard. The electron paramagnetic resonance spectra (EPR) was carried out on a Bruker A300 (9.853 GHz) spectrometer at a normal atmospheric temperature. The H2 temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) and NH3 temperature-programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) experiments were performed using an AutoChem II with TCD detection (Micromeritics, USA). Prior to H2-TPR experiment, 50 mg sample was pretreated at 300°C for 3 h in high purified Ar, and then cooled down to 50°C. Then the reactor temperature was raised to 900°C at a rate of 10 °C/min in H2 (10 vol.%)/Ar (40 mL/min). Before the NH3-TPD experiments, 100 mg catalyst was pretreated under high purified He atmosphere at 500°C for 1 h and cooled down to 50°C. Subsequently, the pretreated catalyst was firstly exposed to a mixture gas of NH3 (20 vol.%)/He (120 mL/min) at 50°C to saturation and then purged in high purified he atmosphere for 1 h. Finally, the temperature was raised to 500°C at a rate of 10 °C/min under he atmosphere. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic performance In order to further increase the NH3-SCR activity of CeO2-TA and reveal the influence of ammonium phosphate introduced amount on its physical-chemical properties and activity, especially the relative competition change of phosphates and sulfates, three kinds of ammonium phosphate amount were introduced into the preparation of CeO2-TA catalyst, and the results are shown in Fig. 1 . According to the results in our previous study [40] and Fig. 1, partial sulfur could be doped into the fabricated CeO2 catalyst via a one-pot hydrothermal method under the action of thiourea, and CeO2-TA exhibits an excellent NH3-SCR activity owing to the optimized surface acidity and reducibility. Interestingly, the introduction of low-amount ammonium phosphate can further enhance the NH3-SCR activity of CeO2-TA and P0.1-CeO2-TA presents better catalytic performance at the tested reaction temperatures, especially the medium-temperature activity. However, the further enhancement of P/Ce molar ratio from 0.1 to 0.5 or 1.0 decreases the NH3-SCR activity of CeO2-TA, which indicates that the introduction of high-amount ammonium phosphate is disadvantageous to its catalytic performance, although P1.0-CeO2-TA still exhibits better catalytic activity than single CeO2. Previous research also indicated that the doping of low-amount phosphorus increased the acidity and de-NO x catalytic performance of single CeO2, but the crystallization of phosphate decreased its NH3-SCR activity when the molar ratio of P/Ce is higher than 0.1 [44,45]. Besides, in order to better evaluate the catalytic performance of P0.1-CeO2-TA, the NO x conversions over the reported SO4 2− or PO4 3− modified Ce-based catalysts are summarized and shown in Table S1. It can be observed that P0.1-CeO2-TA catalyst exhibits good catalytic performance under the high mass GHSV of 200,000 mL/(g·h). Furthermore, in order to simulate the flue gas atmosphere under the actual conditions, the tolerance of P0.1-CeO2-TA catalyst to H2O and SO2 was also tested. The results are shown in Fig. S1. During the SCR reaction, when 100 ppm SO2 was added to the reactor, the NO x conversion rate decreases rapidly in four hours, and then decreases slowly to 60% in the next four hours, which can be attributed to the generation of sulfate species on the catalyst surface, possibly inhibiting the adsorption of NH3 on the active site [46]. When 10 vol.% H2O was further added to the reactor, the NO x conversion rate decreases and remains at around 35%, which may be due to the competitive adsorption of H2O and reactant molecules or/and the deposition of sulfate. In addition, after the removal of H2O and SO2, the NO x conversion rate only restores to be approximately 50%, attributing to the elimination of competitive adsorption and the decomposition of partial ammonium bisulfate (ABS) [47,48]. Furthermore, the deactivation of H2O and SO2 is irreversible, and P0.1-CeO2-TA exhibits poor the anti-poisoning of H2O or/and SO2, which needs to be overcome in its practical application. Therefore, the influence of ammonium phosphate introduced amount on the physical-chemical properties of CeO2-TA were characterized in the following sections, revealing the modified amount of (NH4)3PO4 on the interaction of S and P doping. 3.2 SEM and TEM/HR-TEM characterization SEM images were measured to investigate the influence of ammonium phosphate introduction on the morphology of CeO2-TA, and the results are shown in Fig. 2 . Different from the promotional crystallization effect of thiourea, the introduction of ammonium phosphate suppresses the crystallization of cubic fluorite CeO2 in CeO2-TA and the as-prepared P x -CeO2-TA (x = 0.1, 0.5 and 1.0) catalysts present loose surface morphology, which are composed of refined nanoparticles. However, the introduced amount of ammonium phosphate affects the agglomeration and morphology of the nanoparticles, and P0.1-CeO2-TA exhibits similar nanoparticles to CeO2-TA, but some nanorods exist in P0.5-CeO2-TA and P1.0-CeO2-TA, which might be attributed to the formed CePO4. Due to the promotional effect of low-amount ammonium phosphate introduction on the NH3-SCR activity, the TEM and HR-TEM images of CeO2-TA and P0.1-CeO2-TA were further characterized to investigate the influence of S/P modification on the crystal phase and morphology of cerium oxide. According to the results of our previous research and Fig. 3 , the existence of thiourea during the hydrothermal process contributed to the formation of cubic fluorite CeO2 nanocubes rather than the nanoparticles, but the introduction of low-amount ammonium phosphate depresses this effect and enlarges the diameter of cubic fluorite CeO2 nanoparticles. In addition, the interplanar spacings of cubic fluorite CeO2 are about 0.27 nm for CeO2-TA, which is assigned to the (100) facet [49], while P0.1-CeO2-TA presents different interplanar spacings, including 0.281 nm, 0.288 nm and 0.325 nm, which are assigned to the (100) and (111) facets [50,51]. This indicates that the introduction of low-amount ammonium phosphate regulates the exposed facets and morphology of cubic fluorite CeO2 in CeO2-TA by reducing the effect of thiourea partially [40]. According to the TEM-EDS mappings of CeO2-TA and P0.1-CeO2-TA in Fig. 4 , it can be observed that the introduction of low-amount ammonium phosphate doesn't change the dispersion of the component elements on CeO2-TA surface, and P0.1-CeO2-TA also presents similar highly dispersion of Ce, O and S elements. In addition, the introduction of low-amount ammonium phosphate leads to partial P doped on catalyst surface in form of Ce-O-P species, which had been reported by many previous research [33,45]. 3.3 XRD patterns According to the XRD patterns of P x -CeO2-TA (x = 0, 0.1, 0.5, 1.0) catalysts and the PDF standard cards of CeO2 (PDF: 34-0394), CeOSO4 (PDF: 39-0515) and CePO4 (PDF: 32-0199) in Fig. 5 , it can be found that CeO2-TA presents the main diffraction peaks assigned to the cubic fluorite CeO2, and the existence of thiourea promotes the formation of CeOSO4 crystal owing to a broad diffraction peak appearing at around 23° [52,53]. However, the introduction of low-amount ammonium phosphate not only decreases the intensity of the XRD diffraction peaks assigned to cubic fluorite CeO2, but also restrains the formation of CeOSO4 crystal even if thiourea had been added into the mixed solution before the hydrothermal process. The TEM-EDS mappings in Fig. 4 confirm the existence of S element on P0.1-CeO2-TA surface, thus it can be deduced that amorphous sulfates, rather than CeOSO4 crystal, are mainly formed on the surface of the ammonium phosphate modified CeO2-TA catalyst. In addition, the introduction of low-amount ammonium phosphate promotes the formation of monoclinic CePO4 [54], and the enhancement of P/Ce molar ratio from 0.1 to 1.0 leads the diffraction peaks of cubic fluorite CeO2 gradually decrease and even disappear, but increases the intensity of the diffraction peaks assigned to monoclinic CePO4. And only highly crystallized monoclinic CePO4 are detected in P1.0-CeO2-TA. This demonstrates that the existence of excessive ammonium phosphate not only restrains the formation of CeOSO4 crystal, but also might reduce the amorphous sulfates on CeO2-TA surface due to the formation of large monoclinic CePO4. Previous research indicated that the formation of highly crystallized monoclinic CePO4 was unfavorable to the de-nitration activity of CeO2 [55,56]. Therefore, the introduction of low-amount ammonium phosphate contributes to the formation of highly dispersed amorphous sulfates and CePO4 on cubic fluorite CeO2 surface, thus increases the NH3-SCR activity of CeO2-TA. Meanwhile, excessive ammonium phosphate further promotes the formation of monoclinic CePO4, thus decreases the de-nitration performance of catalyst, and the crystallization of cerium-phosphate/sulfate might be a key factor on affecting the NH3-SCR activity of P x -CeO2-TA (x = 0, 0.1, 0.5, 1.0) catalysts in this study. 3.4 N2 adsorption-desorption Fig. 6 presents the N2 adsorption-desorption curves of P x -CeO2-TA (x = 0, 0.1, 0.5, 1.0) catalysts, which shows a typical type-IV adsorption-desorption isotherm and is correlated to the capillary condensation of the adsorbent in mesopores, demonstrating the presence of mesoporous structure (2-50 nm) [57]. According to IUPAC classification, the capillary-condensation hysteresis loops of isotherms could be attributed to type-H3, indicating the existence of slit-like pores [58]. Meanwhile, the introduction of ammonium phosphate regulates the low-pressure closing point and quantity adsorbed of the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm, thus changes the pore-size distribution and pore-width of CeO2-TA due to the formation of monoclinic CePO4 on catalyst surface. From the pore size distributions in Fig. 7 , it can be found that CeO2-TA presents the bimodal distribution curves with the peak positions located at 3-4 nm and 9-14 nm, respectively. This is mainly attributed to the formation and accumulation of CeOSO4 crystal on catalyst surfaces, which also leads to the partial mesoporous of CeO2 collapse [40]. Interestingly, P0.1-CeO2-TA exhibits similar bimodal pore size distribution curves to CeO2-TA, demonstrating that the partial phosphorylation of cubic fluorite CeO2 or/and the formation of monoclinic CePO4 shows the similar effect of CeOSO4 crystal on the pore-structure of catalyst at the presence of low-amount ammonium phosphate. However, the further enhancement of ammonium phosphate amount causes the smaller pore size distribution peak of CeO2-TA to disappear, and enlarges its second pore size distribution peak. In addition, P0.5-CeO2-TA presents the largest low-pressure closing point of the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm and the widest meso/macro-porous distribution. Therefore, the introduced amount of ammonium phosphate can regulate the phosphorylation degree of CeO2-TA and the formed content of monoclinic CePO4, thus changes the pore structure, BET surface areas and pore volumes of catalysts. As shown in Table 1 , the introduction of ammonium phosphate enlarges the pore width of CeO2-TA and its pore volume, but the BET surface area of P x -CeO2-TA (x = 0.1, 0.5, 1.0) catalysts firstly decreases and then increases when the P/Ce molar ratio was enhanced from 0.1 to 1.0. Interestingly, P0.1-CeO2-TA presents the best de-NO x performance, although it has the lowest BET surface area, which indicates that the specific surface area might not be the key factor on affecting the NH3-SCR activity of catalyst in this study. 3.5 Raman spectroscopic characterization and EPR The Raman spectroscopy was performed to investigate the introduction of ammonium phosphate on the surface structure information and defects of CeO2-TA and the corresponding results are given in Fig. 8 . As shown in Fig. 8, CeO2-TA presents three Raman peaks located at about 263, 465 and 600 cm−1, and the former is attributed to the second-order transverse acoustic (2TA) mode of CeO2 or the disorder in the system [59]. The peak at approximately 465 cm−1 could be assigned to the triply degenerate F2g mode of the symmetric breathing mode of oxygen atoms around cerium ions in cubic fluorite CeO2 [60], and the latter had usually been attributed to the oxygen defects (O2−) induced from the non-stoichiometry of nano-CeO2 crystal [61]. In addition, some Raman peaks higher than 900 cm−1 were detected over the phosphate modified CeO2-TA catalysts, and the Raman spectroscopy located at around 1175 cm−1 was also attributed to the oxygen defects as the same as the peak of 600 cm−1 [62]. Furthermore, several Raman peaks at 900-1100 cm−1 are corresponding to the symmetric and antisymmetric stretching vibrations of P-O bonds for the phosphate modified CeO2-TA catalysts, and P1.0-CeO2-TA presents strong Raman spectroscopy of P-O bonds, especially the peak at 974 cm−1 owing to the formation of large monoclinic CePO4 on catalyst surface. Thus, the introduction of ammonium phosphate contributes to the transformation from cubic fluorite CeO2 to CePO4. The existence of oxygen vacancies on catalysts surface can be further verified by EPR technology. As shown in Fig. 9 , the P x -CeO2-TA (x = 0, 0.1, 0.5, 1.0) catalysts exhibit an EPR signal peak g = 2.002, which can be attributed to the unpaired electrons on the oxygen vacancies [63]. The peak intensity of EPR signal is positively correlated with the oxygen vacancies content. It can be seen that phosphorylation modification reduces the oxygen vacancies concentration of CeO2-TA, and the content of oxygen vacancies further decreases with the increase of P/Ce molar ratio. Theoretically, the presence of oxygen vacancies is conducive to accelerating the electron transfer and improving the adsorption capacity of the catalyst for NH3 [64,65]. However, the high concentration of oxygen vacancies may also cause the “oxygen inhibitory effect”, resulting in the accumulation of excess adsorbed oxygen on catalyst surfaces, hindering the adsorption and oxidation of other reactant molecules [66,67], thereby inhibiting the SCR reaction. In addition, the phosphorylation treatment inhibited the crystallization of CeOSO4 on CeO2-TA, effectively preventing the decrease in the catalytic activity due to the impairment of the synergistic catalysis between surface sulfate and bulk CeO2 caused by bulk sulfate. Hence, the formation of amorphous sulfate species helps increase the content of surface adsorbed oxygen and enhance the redox performance of catalyst, thus promoting the SCR reaction [68,69]. These may be the reason for the best NO x reduction performance but relatively lower oxygen vacancy content by P0.1-CeO2-TA catalyst compared to CeO2-TA. 3.6 Surface chemical properties (XPS) The XPS analysis was performed to investigate the influence of ammonium phosphate introduction on the concentrations and valences of the elements on CeO2-TA surface and the results are given in Fig. 10 , Table 2 and 3 . As shown in Fig. 9(A), the Ce 3d XPS spectra of CeO2-TA can be fitted into eight peaks (u, u', u'', u''', v, v', v'' and v''') using the Gaussian Lorentzian profiles. Among them, the peaks labeled as u' and v' are attributed to Ce3+ while the other peaks are assigned to Ce4+ [70]. Meanwhile, the introduction of ammonium phosphate changes the Binding energies of Ce 3d XPS peaks of CeO2-TA and regulates their intensity, for instance increases the intensity of u' and v' peaks assigned to Ce3+, but the peak of u''' attributed to Ce4+ almost disappears for P1.0-CeO2-TA. Therefore, the introduction of ammonium phosphate can regulate the formation of Ce4+/Ce3+ ion pair on CeO2-TA surface. Previous study showed that the presence of abundant Ce3+ species contributed to inducing the unsaturated chemical bonds and charge imbalance of cubic fluorite CeO2 and increased the content of surface oxygen vacancies via the redox cycle of Ce4+/Ce3+ ion pair as follows: 4Ce4++O2−→4Ce4++2e−/vo+0.5O2→2Ce4++2Ce3++vo+0.5O2, where vo represents oxygen vacancy [71], and thus benefits the NH3-SCR activity of catalyst [72]. Therefore, the molar ratios of surface Ce3+/(Ce3++Ce4+) were calculated using the followed equation: (2) C e 3 + ( % ) = S u ′ + S v ′ ∑ ( S u + S v ) × 100 Herein, S represents the area of the corresponding peak. According to the calculated results in Table 2, it can be found that the introduction of ammonium phosphate decreases the concentration of Ce element on CeO2-TA surface due to the doping of P species, but increases its surface Ce3+/Ce4+ molar ratio. And this effect is further enhanced by increasing the P/Ce molar ratio from 0.1 to 1.0. Fig. 9(B) gives the P 2p XPS spectra of P x -CeO2-TA (x = 0.1, 0.5, 1.0) catalysts, and only one peak of P 2p spectra located at about 133.2 eV was detected on the phosphate modified CeO2-TA catalysts, which is assigned to PO4 3− species [73]. In addition, the enhancement of P/Ce molar ratio from 0.1 to 1.0 increases the intensity of P 2p spectra, thus improves the concentrations of P element or/and PO4 3− species on catalyst surface (Table 2). Combined with the influence of ammonium phosphate introduction on the surface concentrations of Ce/P elements and Ce3+/PO4 3− species, it can be deduced that the doped phosphorus presents in form of CePO4 [32], which is consistent with the XRD results in Fig. 5. According to the results in Fig. 9(C), there exists XPS spectra of S 2p for P x -CeO2-TA (x = 0, 0.1, 0.5, 1.0) catalysts, which could be de-convoluted into two peaks attributed to S6+ species [74]. Interestingly, the introduction of low-amount ammonium phosphate increases the concentration of S6+ species on CeO2-TA surface, although it restrains the formation of CeOSO4 crystal. This indicates that the presence of low-amount ammonium phosphate promotes the formation of highly dispersive amorphous sulfates. However, the further increase of ammonium phosphate amount leads to a sharp decrease of S6+ species on catalyst surface and only 0.5% of S element was detected over P1.0-CeO2-TA (Table 2 and 3). Therefore, the formed large monoclinic CePO4 effectively restrains the formation of amorphous sulfates on catalyst surface, and the surface phosphorylation of cubic fluorite CeO2 is stronger than the sulfation under the action of high-amount ammonium phosphate. As shown in Fig. 9(D), the O 1s XPS pattern of CeO2-TA can be de-convoluted into three peaks located at around 529.5 eV, 531.6 eV and 534.9 eV, which is due to the lattice oxygen in CeO2 (Oα), the surface chemisorbed oxygen (Oβ) and the lattice oxygen in Ce2O3 (Oγ), respectively [40,58]. However, the introduction of low-amount ammonium phosphate causes the peak of Oγ to disappear, but increases the intensity of the peak attributed to Oβ. In addition, the enhancement of ammonium phosphate amount further decreases the intensity of Oα peak and this peak even disappears when the P/Ce molar ratio is 1.0. At the same time, one new O 1s peak was detected over both P0.5-CeO2-TA and P1.0-CeO2-TA, which is assigned to the oxygen in the P-O bonds of monoclinic CePO4 [32]. Due to the high mobility and active, the surface adsorbed oxygen (Oβ) has been usually thought to enhance the catalytic oxidization of NO to NO2, thus benefits the catalytic performance of NO x reduction by promoting the “fast-SCR” reaction of catalyst [75]. According to the calculated surface concentrations of component elements and atomic ratios from Table 2 and 3, it is clear that the introduction of high-amount ammonium phosphate brings a substantial reduction of surface Ce4+ and also increases the surface concentration of Ce3+ due to the formation of monoclinic CePO4, thus improves the calculated surface Ce3+/Ce4+ molar ratio. In addition, the enhancement of P/Ce molar ratio from 0.1 to 1.0 gradually decreases the adsorbed oxygen (Oβ) concentration and the calculated Oβ/Ototal ratio on CeO2-TA surface. Compared to P1.0-CeO2-TA and P0.5-CeO2-TA, P0.1-CeO2-TA presents the lowest surface Ce3+/Ce4+ molar ratio but the highest adsorbed oxygen (Oβ) concentration. These indicate that the redox cycle of Ce4+/Ce3+ ion pair from cerium oxide contributes to improving the surface adsorbed oxygen (Oβ) concentration, but the introduction of high-amount ammonium phosphate effectively restrains this ion pair by converting partial Ce4+ to monoclinic CePO4 even if it increases the surface calculated Ce3+/Ce4+ molar ratio significantly. However, P0.1-CeO2-TA exhibits the highest surface concentrations of total oxygen (Ototal)/adsorbed oxygen (Oβ) and the largest calculated Oβ/Ototal molar ratio due to the formation of highly dispersive amorphous sulfates and CePO4, which might play an important role on its good NH3-SCR activity. 3.7 The properties of redox ability Generally, the redox property has been recognized to play a crucial role on the catalytic cycle in the NH3-SCR process of catalyst due to the optimized activation of the adsorbed reactants [76]. Therefore, the H2-TPR spectra was measured to investigate the influence of ammonium phosphate introduction on the redox ability of CeO2-TA and the results are presented in Fig. 11 . Previous research showed that the H2-TPR peaks of cerium oxide at 200-430°C, 430-600°C and above 700°C were assigned to the reduction of surface active oxygen, deeper interior nanoparticles oxygen and bulk oxygen, respectively [56,77,78]. Interestingly, it was found that the modification of thiourea contributed to inducing one new reduction peak at around 330°C and two super-strong reduction peaks at approximate 594 and 677°C for CeO2-TA, respectively ascribed to the surface active oxygen, the interior nanoparticles oxygen and the CeOSO4 species formed on catalyst surface, thus improved the redox activity of CeO2 catalyst [40]. As shown in Fig. 10, the introduction of low-amount ammonium phosphate restrains the formation of the reduction peak at about 330°C over CeO2-TA and makes its reduction peak at around 594°C slightly shift to a higher temperature, thus decreases the reduction of surface active oxygen and interior nanoparticles oxygen of CeO2-TA. However, P0.1-CeO2-TA presents three super-strong overlapping reduction peaks at 500-700°C, which might be attributed to the reduction of the interior nanoparticles oxygen, the formed active CePO4 at subsurface and highly dispersive amorphous sulfates under the action of low-amount ammonium phosphate [32]. In addition, the introduction of ammonium phosphate decreases the reduction ability of bulk oxygen due to the formation of CePO4 via the reaction of PO4 3− and cubic fluorite CeO2, and the enhancement of P/Ce molar ratio from 0.1 to 1.0 not only further gradually decreases the intensity of reduction peaks attributed to the surface active oxygen and interior nanoparticles oxygen, but also effectively reduces the H2-TPR peaks assigned to the surface amorphous sulfates and active CePO4 at subsurface. Thus, P1.0-CeO2-TA exhibits poor reducibility owing to the formation of large monoclinic CePO4 and its total H2 consumption at 100-700°C is only 9% that of CeO2-TA. Therefore, the introduction of low-amount ammonium phosphate helps to the formation of highly dispersive amorphous sulfates and active CePO4 at subsurface, thus optimizes the redox properties of CeO2-TA although it slightly decreases the reducibility of surface active oxygen and interior nanoparticles oxygen. Meanwhile, the formation of large monoclinic CePO4 is very harmful to the redox properties of the phosphorus modified CeO2-TA catalyst due to the decrease of both amorphous sulfates and cubic fluorite CeO2 when the P/Ce molar ratio is higher than 0.5. 3.8 The properties of surface acidity As described in the introduction, both sulfation and phosphorylation can be used to optimize the surface acidity of catalyst and improve its SCR activity. Therefore, NH3-TPD measurement was performed to investigate the effect of further phosphorylation on the acid sites of CeO2-TA. As shown in Fig. 12 , NH3-TPD curves can be fitted into five sub-peaks, and CeO2-TA has a broad NH3 desorption peak in the temperature range of 50-500°C. Among them, the desorption peaks below 200°C are usually attributed to NH3 species desorbed from weak acid sites, while the desorption peaks at 200-500°C are attributed to NH3 species desorbed from medium-strong acid sites [40]. It is evident that the introduction of ammonium phosphate makes the NH3-TPD spectra of CeO2-TA move to higher temperature, but increases the relative area ratios attributed to peaks II and Ⅲ. Furthermore, the enhancement of P/Ce mole ratio from 0.1 to 1.0 can improve this promotional effect, especially increases the relative area ratio of peak II (Table 4 ). Particularly, the peak V of P1.0-CeO2-TA disappears. Therefore, the formation of active or/and monoclinic CePO4 contributes to improving the weak acid sites and the medium-strong acid sites located at peaks II and Ⅲ, especially the former. Meanwhile, the existence of surface sulfates might help to the weak acid sites located at peak Ⅰ, and P0.1-CeO2-TA presents the broadest distribution of acid sites due to the co-existence of amorphous sulfate species and active CePO4, although its relative area ratio of peak Ⅰ is less than that of CeO2-TA, thus exhibits excellent NH3 adsorption performance in a wide temperature range. 4 Conclusions In this study, ammonium phosphate was introduced to optimize the NH3-SCR activity of CeO2-TA catalyst, and the influence of (NH4)3PO4 introduced amount on the catalytic performance and physical-chemical properties of CeO2-TA were investigated. Firstly, the introduction of low-amount ammonium phosphate inhibits the effect of thiourea structure directing agent on the morphology of cubic fluorite CeO2 and increases the pore volume of catalyst. Secondly, the phosphorylation treatment inhibits the crystallization of CeOSO4 and promotes the formation of highly dispersed amorphous sulfate species and active CePO4 on CeO2-TA surface, thus increases the concentration of surface adsorbed oxygen(Oβ)/total oxygen(Ototal). Meanwhile, the results of EPR demonstrate that phosphorylation treatment reduces the oxygen vacancy content on catalyst surface, especially in the condition that large amount of (NH4)3PO4 is introduced. Furthermore, the formation of amorphous sulfate species and active CePO4 might be responsible for the good redox performance, large medium-strong acid sites and excellent acid site distribution of P0.1-CeO2-TA, which explains for the improved NH3-SCR activity than other catalysts. However, it is worth mentioning that the poor anti-poisoning of H2O and SO2 associated with the P0.1-CeO2-TA catalyst is necessary to be optimized in future research. coredata.dc:description: Herein, three qualities of ammonium phosphate were used to investigate the influence of phosphorylation on the NH3-SCR activity of the CeO2-TA catalyst synthesized via the thiourea hydrothermal method. The results demonstrated that when the molar ratio of P/Ce was 0.1, the introduced ammonium phosphate was beneficial to the formation of highly disperse amorphous sulfates and active CePO4 on CeO2-TA surface, thus enhanced the surface total oxygen/adsorbed oxygen concentrations, the redox properties and the intermediate-strong acid sites of catalyst, which might be responsible for the better NH3-SCR activity of P0.1-CeO2-TA than CeO2-TA. However, the introduction of excessive ammonium phosphate promoted the formation of monoclinic CePO4 and reduced the formed quantity of amorphous sulfates on CeO2-TA surface, which were harmful to the redox properties and acid sites of catalyst. Therefore, the introduced ammonium phosphate decreased the NH3-SCR activity of CeO2-TA when the P/Ce molar ratio increased from 0.1 to 1.0.
coredata.dc:title: Insight into the regulating effect of phosphorylation on the NH3-SCR activity and properties of thiourea modified CeO2-TA catalyst
